Comment: Actually, there are 6 promising changes in the new administration's new plan to stabilize Afghanistan.   No guarantees but these changes are long overdue and give the mission a chance.

Key is pressuring Pakistan using the India card and the threat of withdrawing US financial aid to stop being a haven and enabler for Islamist groups in Afghanistan.

2nd is to let the generals and the forces on the ground manage the war and have the right tools and rules to do so.  (Whatever you might think of Obama as president, he was a lousy general.)

3rd is to stop laying out military planning and operational details and timelines in the media for the convenience of the enemy.

4th is to get the other NATO allies in this war to step up their efforts substantially.

5th is to put Afghanistan leaders and forces on notice that this is not a blank cheque operation extending through infinity.

6th is to refrain from the nation building stuff that has proven costly, problematic and divisive.

Worth a try

Comment: There is an option that would be a better long term solution. Move the Spanish immersion program (SIP) from its location at Ainsworth to a currently unused facility like east Sylvan. This will open up room for 300 students at Ainsworth.

The overall PPS SIP is a great concept and espouses the goals of diversity, accessibility, and inclusion.

However, the SIP at Ainsworth is the dirty little secret of the Westside. It does not meet any of the above goals. There is no diversity, access is difficult, and it is run like an exclusive private school, funded by taxpayer money. Schools overcrowded? No problem, SIP is capped at 26 students per class. Lack of budget for teachers? Not an issue, SIP has assistant teachers for every class!  

How is this even compatible with the PPS equity initiative?

Moving the Ainsworth SIP will help meet its true goals, but there is strong resistance to this because it would inconvenience some privileged families that live in the mansions close to the school.

Comment: I appreciate Mr. Woody's detailed review and analysis of the Ducks performance against Nebraska, but he's only describing the problems. We as fans of Ducks football, know that the problems have persisted since last season. We need to go deeper into the root of these problems, which is the coaching staff, and principally the head coach, Mark Helfrich. 

The lack of discipline on the part of the players and the penalties, the poor execution during critical moments such as the end of the first half against Nebraska, the poor play calling by the coaches, and the overall lack of intensity and focus consistently throughout the game, which was on the road, are all indications of poor preparation and coaching. It all falls to Helfrich. Even though he continues to say that he takes responsibility for it, the most important questions remain... When are you going to do something about it? When are you going to demonstrate that you actually understand the problems and have taken steps to fix it?

Comment: Years ago my wife and I got swept down a very fast moving glacier fed creek. We fell, had water flowing over our heads and were bounced along the bottom on the cobbles. Fortunately she was able to grab a branch and pulled us out of the main flow to the side where the water was slower. We were only in the water for maybe a minute but were freezing cold and our feet were numb. She actually started turning blue. The bad thing is we ended up on the same side we started from and still had to cross it again. I gained a lot of respect for swift, cold water that day and have no desire to repeat the experience. 

Later I spoke with a swift water rescue volunteer who said there is a danger of a persons foot getting trapped under a large, shifted cobble and eventually succumbing to the cold and drowning. I'd never thought about that possibility before.

Comment: Let's consider the kind of housing that has been built in recent years -- expensive highrise and suburban sprawl -- and how inadequate it is for providing affordable housing in a liveable community.  Instead we could be constructing well-planned mid-rise dense neighborhoods with quality of life, nearby shops, mini-parks for kids, pedestrian orientation, mass transit (not the stupid rail, but bus).  It is being done all over the world except here.  Government, funded by a tax on the wealthy, could play a big role in consolidating lots through, yes, condemnation, to create large parcels that can be well-planned.  
This is not rocket science.  There are many models we could follow.  End result could be a sufficient supply of affordable rental housing in wonderful neighborhoods that people would enjoy.  Unfortunately, with our pathetic collection of politicians and apathetic public (especially smug, fat-cat homeowners who call the shots here and could care less), it is unlikely.

Comment: This is nonsense.  I got my pilot's license at 17, then worked in the tech industry for twenty years to fund all my certs and ratings and avoid debt.  I worked as a flight instructor, then got hired by an outfit in Alaska.  

I flew there for two years.  

Fourteen hours a day for $160-$200/day of high-risk, physically- and mentally-exhausting flying. 

Then starting pay at the airlines -doubled-, and I went to the airlines.

I will be LUCKY if I break $30k/gross this year, living in an area with one of the highest costs-of-living in the country.  I fly a jet, carrying 80 main-line passengers on such legs as Dallas-San Francisco, Chicago-Reagan National, Austin-Los Angeles, and so on.  

Next year is only a tiny increase in pay, as is the year after.  It is, in fact, very unlikely I'll EVER make more than I made at 18, in my first year in tech.

Even if pay TRIPLED from where it is now, and ten years from now I was looking at $200k, professional pilots should never be paid this little.

Comment: A couple of observances as we enter the final day of filing for the primary in August:

1. The amount of candidates that are entering this race is quite astounding. For a winner take-all proposition, what I see happening is that the deck is being loaded with so many names that no one is going to surpass the 50% threshold to win the office outright in August. 
2. From that group, which will count 10 today with the entry of Djou, I can see where there are the "wanna keep Caldwell under 50%" group, and then the "make it into the top 2 or three to survive into the general". I would imagine the big names in the race are running for the latter. 
3. While there are so many things that a candidate could focus on for this race, the two that stand out is rail and homeless. As for each of them, it will be interesting if any of the big name candidates comes out with anything more novel to address homelessness. As for Rail, I will call it that the proposals will be tweaks more than sweeping changes

Comment: During the '70s and '80s, we had massive "open field" burning in the Willamette Valley, virtually covering much of the valley in a thick pall of smoke. The grass-seed industry screamed "You are killing the industry"....that industry thrives twenty years later and there's a profitable market for the straw left after the harvest.

Unfortunately corporations and huge private industries all too often place their own profit above, far above, the concern for their actions impact on others.  Laws and regulations protect neighbors and the general public from such selfishness and lack of consideration for others. 

Some advocate for a total ban on aerial spraying.  The Donnilles are lobbying for sensible buffer zones.  There's a very real difference and they present a compromise which could be as much of a "win-win" as this contentious issue offers.  regards, Gary Crum

Comment: Thousands of years ago all humans hunted wild animals and gathered wild plants to live. Then the plant and animal kingdoms underwent a profound change and split into two broad groups. There were still wild animals and plants but slowly a new group emerged; the domestic animals and plants. As time when on more and more people survived by raising animals and plants in a controlled situation which in the long run was more reliable that hunting high and low for things to eat. In some parts of the world wild plants and animals were entirely replaced by the domestic ones. Alaska is an exception to what happened in the rest of America where only small bands of the wild ones survive. 
Well over a million humans fish, gather and hunt Alaska each year. Mostly they don't need to do this since mostly they live near a well stocked store. They do it because they can. Few ask whether in 2016 they should do it. Few seem to see the wild populations are all becoming smaller year by year. Think about it.

Comment: ‪#‎Second‬, while shale costs have dropped and are low in the so-called "sweet spots", they will firm as drilling -- and thus, demand for drilling services -- pick back up and as drilling expands again beyond the sweet spots into the more costly areas. ‪#‎Third‬, given the massive and historic level of global underinvestment on the supply side over the past two years (for example, in 2015 recoverable resources discovered from conventional wells outside of North America was at its lowest level since 1952), shale alone isn't going to fill the gap and thus, isn't going to set the marginal cost/price of supply. Once again, it will take big projects to do that.Wohlforth is correct at the end that Alaska projects will need to compete "for every [investment] dollar, like everyone else," but that's nothing new. Alaska always has competed for global investment dollars; no investor has ever said "let's put dollars into Alaska even if we have better returns elsewhere."
(Excerpted. By B. Keithley)

Comment: Mr. Dunlap's claims that "WSF tries to make our ferry service a for-profit venture," and that WSF should "dip into [its] all important profit margin" for added funds are sadly misinformed   In the latest period for which data is available, fare revenue for the domestic San Juans route covered only 51.9% of operating expenses; for the entire network that figure was 72.9%, so our operation is more heavily subsidized than is the system as a whole.

Note I speak only of OPERATING expenses, currently over $200 million for all routes.  Capital costs--boats, terminals and their ongoing upkeep that also are in excess of $200 million annually--are paid entirely by state funds, aside from the 25 cents per ticket which totals only about $6 million annually.

So profit?  What profit?

Bob Distler
Orcas

Comment: By the shear volume of raising the issue anytime someone thinks it will "stick".  Like the proverbial "boy who cries wolf" too many times, people start to "tune out" the issue.  Whether this particular letter falls into that category is a matter of opinion. I think it does. At any rate, I want to raise the issue because I think race relations in this country are deteriorating, not getting better. (I know, a real understatement - huh.) I see stories in which it's pretty clear that actual racism is involved and in which harm is done being greeted with a "ho-hum, what else is new" response from people. I see it in letters, comments, and I hear it from people who I used to hear different responses from. Why? I don't profess to have the answers, but I want to see it get turned around. Race relations has been the single most intractable problem in this country in my lifetime.

Comment: That U.S. Air Force poster titled "From Raptors to Stilts" has nothing to do with the fact that F-22's are deadly tools - it's a play on words in the sense that Raptors and Stilts are two types of birds.  The Pu'wai wetland restoration depicted by the poster is a good thing, regardless of the organization responsible for funding it.  Four endangered Native Hawaiian waterbirds are increasingly returning to the area thanks to the hard work of many people, including hundreds of volunteers from the local community.  The ongoing work there has been instrumental in the removal of invasive species, planting native species, building roosting and foraging habitat, and ensuring protection from predators.  Say what you will about the military mission at-large, they are engaged in important conservation work as evidenced by their booth presentations at the IUCN, and you don't have to agree with the presence of the military in Hawaii to acknowledge that fact.

Comment: Not to be too anal, but you mean VPSO (Village Public Safety Officer), not VSPO. And I believe Wassillie, the victim, was a VPO (Village Police Officer), not a VPSO. There is a big difference. A VPSO goes through state training & is recognized & supervised & paid by the state. There are way more VPOs than VPSOs. VPOs get a lot less training, & none of it is from the state that I know of. VPOs get lower pay, & VPOs are not officially recognized by the state due to the state's  opposition to tribal sovereignty. VPOs are paid & supervised by tribal councils. VPOs have high turnover & are often very young guys. VPSOs are meant to be a career option & have longer term professionals, generally. Comment: Spirit, Federal law distinguished between the organized militia and the unorganized militia.  If you belong to the National Guard or the Naval Militia, you belong to the organized militia, which is well regulated.  The unorganized militia is not well regulated.  If you don't like it, you can try to change the law.
"10 U.S. Code § 246 - Militia: composition and classes
(a) The militia of the United States consists of all able-bodied males at least 17 years of age and, except as provided in section 313 of title 32, under 45 years of age who are, or who have made a declaration of intention to become, citizens of the United States and of female citizens of the United States who are members of the National Guard.
(b) The classes of the militia are—
(1) the organized militia, which consists of the National Guard and the Naval Militia; and
(2) the unorganized militia, which consists of the members of the militia who are not members of the National Guard or the Naval Militia."

But if Senate Democrats seeking to bait and interrogate him weren’t particularly interested in his profession of innocence, it was hardly surprising. As was made plain by their questioning of former FBI director James Comey and the three intelligence chiefs last week, Democrats have moved the goalposts on the Russia investigation. They’ve all but given up on their quest to prove the Trump campaign colluded with Moscow to influence the 2016 election — the charge at the heart of the ongoing congressional investigations. Comment: Unless and until we commodify our water, we will treat it as if it has no value.  The world is a thirsty place and Canada has the water the world needs.  By bottle, by tanker or by pipeline we should be selling our water to those who will pay for it.

We have a natural resource the Saudis can only be envious of.  When their oil is burned, it's bad for the environment.  When it is gone, it's gone.  When a better, cheaper or more environmentally benign energy source becomes available, their resource becomes worthless.

Our water is 100% renewable, plentiful, can be harvested with little to no environmental impact and if husbanded carefully is a resource that will enrich Canada for generations.  And it can never be replaced by an alternative product.  Once consumed by the end-user to whom we export it, the only thing they will need is more.

As Canadians, we are absolutely foolish if we don't capitalise on the bounty that our water will provide for Canada and for its consumers worldwide.

The "Crest Drive Street Design" (CDSD) project was a _staff-led_ process that began in 2006. It was led by Lisa Gardner, who was a Public Works Department (PWD) transportation planner at the time.  Gardner touted her "success" using a novel approach to street planning, called "context sensitive solutions" (CSS).

The City's press release described CSS as "a collaborative project development approach involving all stakeholders to develop a transportation facility that fits into its physical surroundings while maintaining safety and mobility for all users and reflecting community needs."

Recommendations were developed by a "Crest Drive Community Team", a committee of neighborhood residents and City staff, through a lengthy, contentious public process _that was directed by staff_.

CDSD was _not_ at all "a poster child for citizen-centered planning -- it was a giant _staff_ fail.

Comment: My father was a mechanical engineer, who didn't get a PhD for an unusual reason: He finished his dissertation before he finished his coursework. In the mid-1950s, he was hired by Penn State to do a specific piece of research on diesel fuels, and the university told him he could use it for his dissertation. It was expected that it would take him three years and he finished it in 18 months. It was published, and on the strength of it, Shell Oil offered him a job at three times the salary Penn State was paying him. Comment: Trade deals may have gone too far and grown too be too complex. But let us not forget that the mother of multi-national trade deals, the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC), was formed in years following WW2.  The objective was to remove these two key industries from control by nationalistic politics by submitting them to multi-national regulations, and with that to reduce the risk of international industrial disputes from exploding into military wars. The  ECSC was the seed from which the EU emerged. 
One need only compare the first half to the second have of the 20th century in Europe to recognize that this multinational economic deal achieved what it was designed to achieve.

We should think about that before going back to championing economic nationalism.

Thereby the bill reduces incentives for plea agreements and is going to cause even more backlog in the court system, while people line up to get their slap on the wrist.

The law prevents judges from imposing almost any time in jail for probation violations like not doing treatment, contacting victims, and not showing up for probation appointments. Comment: Over the long term, business will survive only through innovation, innovation and innovation. Innovation attracts talented workforces, it creates barriers to entry in industry (would you prefer to buy your iPhone from Apple or Google?), and it attracts consumers to products. All of these maximize shareholder value. The failure of President Trump to be focused on innovation is unfortunate. Just recently, he overturned Climate Change regulations on automobiles that had spurred the development of loss-leading electric cars. Tesla is now worth more in the stock market than Ford or GM as measured in market capitalization. In 60-70 years, the developed world's automobile markets will consist almost entirely of electric vehicles. While it is very unfortunate when any job is disposed of (because it provides human dignity), the president is focused on the dying industry of coal. Is the US going to be left behind?

Comment: Rent control are not fair to landlords of condo units, especially those built pre-1991. Unlike apartment buildings, condo buildings are incorporated and have an elected Board of Directors. Every year the Board develops a budget and determines how much the maintenance fees need to be increased to cover costs. From my experience this increase ranges from 1.5% to 4%, with increases being higher for older buildings that typically need more maintenance. If you also add on the property tax increases enacted by Council, a landlord's costs can increase between 2.8% and 5.3% (this assumes a property tax increase of 1.3%).

For condo units built pre-1991, the rent guidelines only allow a rent increase of between 1.5% and 2%. This means that landlords of these units are more than likely not able to recoup a significant portion of the increased costs, which is not fair or equitable. Landlords should be able increase rent by the same increase to maintenance fees and property taxes.

Comment: I'll offer an alternative view in good faith... Informative trail signs in the backcountry can be a boon to safety, but there's nothing wrong with expecting trail users in an urban area to have some idea of where they are by using a trail map or their own judgment. A fair number of large, obtrusive signs with no information on them have been erected to no purpose, other than to advertise who put them up. The smaller kiosk-style, information-laden signs will help those who can't help themselves. But the expensive, billboard-style placards without information are overkill. The South Platte corridor is now badly over-signed. Just sayin' there's a limit that should be based on what's useful, in good taste, and a wise use of taxpayer monies.

Comment: Not all customers are the same, of course.  Frontier is seeing a lot of growth (even more than SWA, I think) with the ULCC business model.

I love SWA for the most part, as they've managed to find a way to do just as you said - offer decent services at a very competitive price.  They're sort of the Sams Club (or Costco) of airlines.  It's a great model, to be sure.  And they've had great success perfecting it.

But United, American, Delta etc can't seem to match them.  In part because they don't limit themselves to just shorter-haul North America flights.  And they don't offer the higher-end service that many business travelers are willing to pay for. They're broader range of offerings end up with a higher-cost operation on the whole, it seems.  

What most customers want is low fares.  That's a big part of why SWA and Frontier and other discount airlines have seen so much growth in the last few decades.

Comment: It's not measurably possible that Native people did the "same" thing to each other as was done to them.  When Europeans arrived here this was a land absolutely brimming over with life.   There were well over 500 separate languages spoken in the lower 48 alone, as well as countless wildlife in every part of the land, and abundant fish and resources.   The accounts from the 1800s in California speak of whales so abundant that they could be seen, heard and smelled from the beaches, and in fact, the odor of them from their numbers was overwhelming.   Native Americans have been here at least 13,000 years, and maybe as long as 23,000.   

When the Europeans were finished with their "Indian Wars," there were only maybe 3%, maybe fewer, of the original populations of American Indians left alive.   Numerous species were already exterminated, and others in extreme decline.

It's not possible to do the "same" thing and get such vastly different results.   Not in measurable reality, it's not.

Comment: You are welcome to believe the myths, but the consensus of military historians is that Dieppe was a debacle and nothing much was learned. This consensus is best expressed by perhaps the most respected Canadian military historian (and former Canadian Army veteran, Jack Granatstein:

"There was heavy bombing, though it was not hugely successful in destroying beach defences. There was massive naval gun support, which was successful. There were better landing craft and specialized armoured vehicles, and the assault troops were far better trained. All of those things would likely have happened even without the Dieppe raid."

"Some lessons were learned, but most of them were lessons that had been mastered before. Many of them had been taught at staff colleges for decades. Most of them were simple common sense."
Dieppe: A Colossal Blunder

Comment: Romeo Saganash, should be commended for this piece. Like too many First Nations people, he has overcome so many blows, blows delivered by fellow Canadians: Only to rise up, time and time again, to give voice in opposition of oppression.  In many places around the world, his critical words would place his life and liberty in jeopardy. But not here. Even if he were not an MP, he could speak out, without fear of imprisonment or retribution. This article and its publication today represents the best and the worst that Canada has to offer: Both discrimination and our never ending struggle against discrimination. I sympathize with plight of our first Nation Brothers and sisters. We must do much more to make amends for past wrongs and to help them build for themselves and for all of us, a better tomorrow.
I am glad that the Globe published this piece on Canada Day. It reminds of  our glaring imperfections but is also a triumph of our freedom and democracy. So with that said. Happy Canada Day!

Comment: One of the reasons we have elected governments is that we expect those governments to deal with the things we neither have the time for nor the expertise. While various opinion writers make a living from telling us what we are not doing, how we are wrong or how we ought to live, the average Canadian is just trying to get through the daily living process, without taking on the sadder aspects of life. It's a mistake to think that people don't think about the these issues, but the reality is that people long ago accepted the fact that it doesn't matter. Governments run on platforms that supposedly echo what we want or what we are told we want, and then routinely break all these promises. Why would we possibly think that we could actually influence governments on matters that they obviously don't care about. In many respects people are suffering from lecture fatigue. We can't go through a day without being told what we should de doing, and that has lead to selective deafness.

Comment: It will be interesting to see how Alberta deals with pot sales and compare that to Ontario. I have a feeling that Alberta's pot sales policies will make Ontario's look as draconian as their alcohol sales policies.

Example- Alberta privatized alcohol sales in 1993. Their provincial alcohol sales policies are still strictly controlled by the Alberta Gaming & Liquor Commission. However, the number of private alcohol sales stores, hours of operation and products available have expanded greatly from the days of government run sales outlets. Alberta now has about 22,000 different alcohol products available to consumers, from everywhere in the world, compared to Ontario's 14,000.  Alberta's government revenue from alcohol sales has also increased proportionally, while creating about 5-times as many private sector jobs.

It's kind of funny that Alberta has a more 'liberal' outlook to alcohol sales than does Ontario. I think their pot sales policies will be the same!

Adding insult to injury, millions of board feet of our best timber is being sold by the ton instead of by log scale.

Comment: I saw another production of this work in Vancouver, some years ago, so i can't comment on the recent Toronto production.  However, the reviewer's comments on the music are spot-on. Somers was a Toronto personality, and turned out a lot of music, but none of it is listenable today, and none of it is played. This particular score is unrelievedly grey and musically unmotivated except by an occasional brutalist frenzy. The only reason it was revived was because of continuing interest in the subject matter, but that is no reason to revive an opera. If the music were any good, no one would be talking about distortion and misappropriation in the libretto (well maybe they would, but it would be beside the point). Does anyone worry about historical authenticity in any of the great operas in the repertoire?

Nationalized health care is no panacea.

Comment: First, note that the survey question used these buzz words:

invasive
mainland species
spread a disease
deadly 
maintain Hawaii’s ecosystem
extinction

In this question, these cats had no chance!

Second, there is never a discussion about how difficult a proposition cat removal is.  Yes, there is the low-hanging fruit... cats at Hawaii Kai, or on the UH campus.  Let's say those 2 populations total 400 cats.  Then 300,000 minus 400 equals... 299,600.  I don't think the toxoplasmosis population will notice the difference.

Third, even those first 400 cats being euthanized come at a cost.  Somebody has to trap these animals (plus the cost of the traps and the regular monitoring of these traps to prevent trap-induced mortality), somebody has to scan the animals for identification chips (cats must be held for at least 48 hours with no ID; and at least 9 days with ID), and somebody has to purchase and apply the euthanasia drugs.

Nathan, you need to ask the right questions.

Comment: Not sure what the logic is behind the assertion you should only have US stocks in an RRSP?

The only relevant factor of when it comes to an RRSP or any registered account is the tax implication.  Generally speaking you want to avoid holding stocks or investments in an RRSP if upon withdrawal the money will be subject to a higher rate of tax.

The only difference (for your typical investor) between US stocks and Canadian stocks in this regard is the taxation of eligible Canadian dividends.  So while it may make more sense to keep Canadian dividend stocks in cash account or TFSA that doesn't equate to saying your RRSP should only hold US stocks.  It really depends on your current and expected future tax rate, as well as your overall portfolio composition.

Comment: I believe that GCI and their fellow group of supporters are very sincere in their efforts to solve the state budget crisis.  Sure, there are selfish reasons for their efforts, but closing the budget gap is beneficial to all Alaskans who intend to live here for the long term.  Using permanent fund earnings as well as cutting state budgets, enacting new taxes and reducing oil industry subsidies are all part of the solution.  Most of the comments I have read regarding this article offer no solutions to solving the budget crisis.  Those who have placed themselves in a financial position that requires the PFD to make ends meet have made a financial planning mistake.  By the way, I don't hear anyone complaining about the money they have saved due to lower fuel costs.
Governor Walker's plan to close the budget gap is reasonable and necessary, with room for some tweaks.

Comment: The US had a good case against Canadian softwood lumber, we were violating NAFTA when provincial governments set stumpage fees that were not subject to market demand, and were lower than market-based fees elsewhere. They argued, convincingly, that this qualifies as an unfair government subsidy to the industry. Much of the legal fighting was about whether the retaliatory tariffs were at appropriate levels (the media heralded some of these as wins for Canadian industry, when really the rulings were saying 'tariffs are fair, but these ones are too high').

Beef was different. There were legitimate concerns about the spread of BSE, a threat to human health, although there were reasonableness questions to the restrictions there also.

Comment: It might improve civil discourse if you'd use your real name. 
That point aside, I get what you're saying. If you never go there, you may feel like it shouldn't cost you anything because it doesn't serve your needs. I happen to disagree. The pool does serve all of us, by making our community healthier, providing a safe place for kids to hang out and have fun on a Friday night, giving Navy personnel a place to stay fit, and helping older adults stay active. All this in addition to vital swim instruction that gives kids life skills from basic strokes all the way up to lifeguard training -- lifeguards who may well save your life or that of someone you love one day. In any case a healthier community benefits all of us.
Every program I mentioned charges a user fee, a significant one. The levy just helps to open the doors and keep warm, clean water in the pool.

Comment: It's true governments don't determine it, but they can have an impact on the margin.  The NDP cannot cause or prevent another recession, but things like saying no to all resource projects, making corporate and top marginal tax rates uncompetitive, giving labour unions too much power can make BC an unattractive place to do business.  Most businesses won't leave, but only 5% leaving will have a negative impact and also many others thinking of setting up shop here won't bother while in power.  Essentially governments can move the needle about 0.5% in GDP growth in either direction so 0.5% less than what it would be under a BC Liberal government is not devastating, but in power for enough years it can add up to quite a bit, that's 5% less in size if in power for 10 years.

Comment: Once again the Star-Advertiser is glossing over facts.  The $325 million cost estimate in the report isn't for a replacement stadium with "30,000 to 40,000 seats."  Rather the report states plainly in black and white that the cost estimate is based on building a stadium with 31,000 seats.  Elsewhere in the report there is a consultant recommendation to build a replacement stadium with 30,000 to 35,000 seats that would be "expandable" to 40,000 for special events, but that is NOT what spending $325 million would deliver.  The cost estimate was not done by that consultant but rather by a Stadium Authority engineer who assumed a capacity of 31,000, period.

A facility almost 40% smaller than what we have today will NOT meet the needs of a growing Oahu population over the next 50 years.  Settling for a shoebox stadium would be as foolish and shortsighted as it would have been to build the Stan Sheriff Center with only 4,000 seats as some originally advocated.  NO TO THE SHOEBOX.

Comment: Many Asian women did indeed provide “comfort” services to the Japanese Imperial Forces during World War II, but I do not believe they did it at the point of a gun nor was it sexual slavery.    Throughout history, military forces have had no problem finding “comfort women” regardless of the country in which they operated and they were able to find them without kidnapping, coercion or threats of any kind.  Wars create horrible conditions which cause people to resort to often unthinkable means to survive.  For many women, it was the use of their bodies, and there usually was more supply than demand.  I personally witness this during the Korean War and during two years in Vietnam.  Some members of the Imperial Japanese forces no doubt forced women to have sex, which, of course, is rape, but I believe the “comfort women” who served the Imperial Japanese forces in brothels that sprung up and operated near Japanese bases did so voluntarily for pay.

Comment: Randall,

The full story regarding PET has a significantly darker opening but a more profound and admirable conclusion.

As Max &Monique Nemni's well research book "Young Trudeau" well describes, during his first 25 or so years, PET was caught up in the ethnic, religious, ultra-nationalism all to prevalent amongst the middle classes in France and Francophone Quebec of that period; even to the point of speculating in an amateurish way with friends instigating armed insurrection of a quasi-fascist nature.

Education abroad, reflection and life experience by the early 1950s had led P. E. Trudeau to abandon such obscurist and narrow thinking and the progressive thinker, opinion leader and political figure that is remembered today emerged.

Whether one agrees or disagrees with most of what this later PET represented, one must admire his intellectual courage and honesty.

Comment: There is a population in Anchorage that needs a more secure mental health care than the assisted living homes around town provide. These people end up having a crisis which brings them to the emergency room and then to API. While in API they lose cash benefits that go towards paying for their assisted living home. Some of these people will be discharged without a place to go and they end up on the street and seek shelter for the nights. These people cannot care for themselves yet are released to fend for themselves as our Alaskan winter temperatures drop. Once these people are on the street it becomes even more difficult to find them safe housing and often the assisted living homes with refuse them for one reason or another. There are some very good assisted living homes but there are many horrible ones that abuse these people. Something more needs to be done for the population that cannot care for themselves through no fault of their own.

Comment: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_on_Drugs

The War on Drugs" is an American term commonly applied to a campaign of prohibition of drugs, military aid, and military intervention, with the stated aim being to reduce the illegal drug trade. This initiative includes a set of drug policies that are intended to discourage the production, distribution, and consumption of psychoactive drugs that the participating governments and the UN have made illegal. The term was popularized by the media shortly after a press conference given on June 18, 1971, by United States President Richard Nixon—the day after publication of a special message from President Nixon to the Congress on Drug Abuse Prevention and Control—during which he declared drug abuse "public enemy number one".

Today, the Drug Policy Alliance, which advocates for an end to the War on Drugs, estimates that the United States spends $51 billion annually on these initiatives.

War on Drugs did not create Drug Cartels.

Comment: I kind of disagree on this point... building taller does not imply the best of densification.

Paris France is incredibly dense, yet few buildings are over 7 or 8 floors high.  Similar case in Washington DC where no buildings can be taller than the Washington Monument

As a Torontonian, it is my own personal opinion that the glorification of height, at the expense of all else, has led to urban canyons devoid of the street life that creators of density crave to have. People don't feel connected to street life when they can shut themselves away on the 40th floor of a building. Also, if you've ever tried to sit out on a balcony on a 40th floor apt suite, then you know it can be as unpleasant as all heck with the dusty wind gusts that permeate the upper floors of too-tall towers.

If developers gave more thought towards preserving a neighbourhood feel, as opposed to foisting 50, 60 or 70 storey towers to replace 2 and 3 storey streetfronts, then I believe there'd be much less opposition.

Comment: The most likely reason is that it is not comfortable for Western journalists to report from these places.

Just before Christmas 1980 I was in Kano, Nigeria when the Maitatsine riots broke out. For days the second largest city in Africa's most populous countries was convulsed. The official death toll was over 4,000 and this was likely low. There were arrows flying in the lorry park. The Nigerian Air Force was making supersonic runs on the old city where Maitatsine's followers were holed up. There were no stories in the international press.

At the time there were plenty of stories about apartheid. Could it have been that it was much more comfortable to stay in four star hotels in Johannesburg and drive out to Soweto where the security forces would keep them safe?

Comment: I'm an independent contractor with a pretty good income - and I can't afford even bad healthcare here anymore. This is like the 4th year of 25% year over year increases from HMSA. Health insurance shouldn't cost more than our food. The current system of employer-based group plans (which is most people in Hawaii) is deliberately engineered to hide the costs. Under the typical state or city plan each worker is expending over $20k per year for that plan when the employer contribution is counted. And that needs to be counted - it's not extra money your employer had lying around, it's money that could have paying you more. It's effectively a healthcare tax, but taken before the money even hit your pocket, so you never missed it. And you didn't have a choice about it - try refusing your employer-based plan and then asking for that employer contribution back as salary. The USA really is the laughing stock of the first world. I'm a scientist - I know many who left the US for this reason.

Comment: The ridiculous thing is that, although English is a 'universal' language, every country and local region, have ways of using English peculiar to itself; if the liturgy is to be truly meaningful to each community only one English translation does not suffice. Comment: It needs to be honest science, though..   There is science that disregards the simple in favour of falsehood or complexity for reasons that have no basis in true science.   

I'm not talking about theories that evolve and are refined over time.   I'm talking about situations where concepts are disregarded for reasons that have nothing to do with anything scientific.   

A great example would be when Galileo argued that the earth revolved around the sun and when he published a book on the subject, he was imprisoned by the Pope.   People believed the sun revolved around the Earth and it was an affront to the worldview of those in power for him to publicly argue anything different.

At the same time, Galileo believed the planetary orbits were circular, which was wrong.   It was Kepler who later proved the planetary orbits were elliptical yet  Galileo made huge contributions to the advancement of scientific understanding of planetary motion which Kepler, Newton, and others later refined.

Comment: "We may be testing that out when millions of pot puffers get behind the wheels of their cars."

Rich, pot is already easily available to anyone who wants it; virtually nobody who wants to try pot is stymied by prohibition. So I'm not sure why you think "millions of [new] pot puffers" will suddenly appear on the roads. Can you explain?

"One possible result: many, many more abusers, because shooting up, toking up, sniffing up will be even more socially acceptable--oh, hey, and safer!--than it is today."

That's one _possible_ result, but consider this: the most effective way to reduce smoking rates turned out to be regulations that make it socially difficult to smoke. The use of currently-illegal drugs is _already_ highly proscribed among the general public due to decades of demonization of drug users, so it's difficult to imagine legalization suddenly changing this. 

Also, would you start taking heroin if it was legalized tomorrow? No? Nor would most, I suspect.

Comment: In Missouri,  first degree murder is defined as knowingly causing the death of another person after deliberation. Second degree murder is defined as knowingly causing the death of another person. The sole distinction is the element of deliberation.  Second degree murder is, therefore, a "lesser included offense." meaning that if the judge or jury found that the defendant had satisfied all the elements except for deliberation, the proper verdict would have been second degree murder.  So if the prosecutors overcharged, it would not have been to their detriment, except morally.

Comment: The Electoral College is not a vestige of slavery. It is a vestige of the world's first experiment with the new type of government known as federalism. The electors were nothing more than the interface between the national (federal) government and each of the state governments. Seats for electors were apportioned to states, and it was up to the states to figure out who to send and how they should vote. It is certainly true that the apportionment of the number of seats was in accordance with "The Three-fifths Compromise," to appease slave states, but the Fourteenth Amendment ended it.

The problem people have with the Electoral College is that all states but two award all their electoral votes to the winner in each state. If states awarded electoral votes proportionally, the Electoral College result would match the popular vote closely. Support the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact to fix the problem.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Popular_Vote_Interstate_Compact

Comment: "knowledge of child abuse in the creation of the image"  does not appear in either Oregon or Federal statutes.

In fact, you can get 10 years in Federal prison if no actual person is depicted.

Federal Law:

 " Section 2256 of Title 18, United States Code, defines child pornography as any visual depiction of sexually explicit conduct involving a minor (someone under 18 years of age).  Visual depictions include photographs, videos, digital or computer generated images indistinguishable from an actual minor, and images created, adapted, or modified, but appear to depict an identifiable, actual minor.  Undeveloped film, undeveloped videotape, and electronically stored data that can be converted into a visual image of child pornography are also deemed illegal visual depictions under federal law."

https://www.justice.gov/criminal-ceos/citizens-guide-us-federal-law-child-pornography

"indistinguishable from an actual minor," is the key there.  

Your bogus assertions are just wrong.

Comment: I'm a cab driver and a plate owner. The author did his homework, but he is telling one side of the story to make it juicy.

Plates no longer cost $360,000 but instead they go for about $100,000. Also, income earn from a taxi drivers has been halved, since Uber has taken most of the business. Given these figures, the traditional taxi industry should be extinct.  Just look at the numbers, If a driver was clearing about $120 in a bad day, he's now clearing $60 because Uber has taken over 1/2 pie.  

I'm sure Uber is smarting over the fact that the taxi industry has not collapsed since they're hemorrhaging billions to take it over.  Reason being, is because these supposed despot taxi plate holder have waved all but a token amount of the fees they're been collecting for their taxi plates. And in some case, they've been digging into their own pockets to keep the car on the road.  Consequence is that it's now cheaper to drive a taxi cab owned by someone else vs putting your own on the road.

Comment: Our health care system got screwed up way back in the late 1940's and early 1950's when 3rd-party-payor group health insurance was introduced to circumvent government wage controls.  For the first time in this country's history, the consumer could buy goods and services with someone else's money, and the natural price constraints of the free market system were removed from the equation.  The cost of health care has been spiraling upward since.

The only way to bring health care costs down is to return it to free market incentives with a National HSA Program for the first $10,000 per year as the only option.  If you don't spend it, you keep the money.  That'll introduce competition and eliminate claims processing costs, while reducing the cost of health care by 40-50%.   Who objects?  Insurance companies and claims processors who are removed from the picture, except for claims over $10,000, which is only 5% of the claims.  The average person under 65 incurs less than $4,000/yr.

Comment: Ms. Beyak is from NW Ontario so she likely has some personal insight.  I have a number of friends who went to the local residential school.  If they wanted a basic education, that was where they had to go, both native and non-native.  It's a sad narrative that young children were removed from their reserve homes remote from school and that some were abused during that process.  However, not all the teachers/instructors/administrators were pedophiles; many worked with the best of intentions towards their charges.  Like the native residential schools, young students of my generation and earlier generations, no matter where they went to school, were often physically abused for reasons of discipline.  And why, even today, are First Nation organizations bringing young students from remote communities to a "segregated" residential high school in Thunder Bay where there still seems to be issues with students being able to cope with the move.

Comment: The NDP has nearly destroyed Medicare.

Former NDP leader Tommy Douglas was responsible for the first provincial Medicare program in Saskatchewan before it became a federal program. The Sask NDP borrowed the idea from a Saskatchewan municipal medical plan. (When the Sask government implemented Medicare it was an extremely controversial idea. Even after long periods of provincial NDP government, citizens reacted like the US Tea Paryy on steroids.) 

Tommy Douglas introduced Medicare so that people would not go bankrupt not so that people could receive free treatment for a bad cold. He believed that patients should always pay a user fee even if governments could afford to forgo such fees. (The provincial governments pretend that they can afford to fund Medicare with current Medicare fees but have a coronary when the federal government balks at transferring ever lather amounts of money.

It is not politically correct to say this in Canada but our system is not economically sustainable.

Comment: Instead, HSTA should try to restructure the DOE to improve student learning.  Currently, the DOE is too top-heavy, and the bureaucrats in the central office justify their existence by issuing directives to school administrators and teachers.  They have little experience with the conditions at the schools themselves, and as a result, many of these directives are ineffective.  The school faculty becomes overburdened by having to comply with directives that they know won't work.  That's why the morale of teachers and principals is at a historic low.

HSTA should try to restructure the DOE to give teachers more authority to determine how they will teach their students.  After all, they know their students best.  The teachers and principal at each school should work collaboratively to determine the curriculum and instruction at that school.  That would allow them to work as the professionals that they are.

Comment: Furthermore, you didn't hit of the merits from the article. 

No matter how we fish here in Hawaii that doesn't change the fact that Hawaii's demand for fish is skyrocketing and is only going to grow. In fact, globally the demand for seafood has quadrupled since the 1960's. This is a large problem even if Hawaii is fishing 'sustainably'. Even so, we export a large amount of our catch outside Hawaii compounding the problem. 63% of the seafood we eat here in Hawaii is Haole/foreign and who knows the quality. Case in point the recent Hep A outbreak from Indonesian Ahi cubes.

My main point is that we should be valuing and prioritizing our natural capital over our own selfish means. We actually get more in return by practicing this value. Our current growth economy isn't working. You don't need to have a PHD and 20 years working as an economist to figure that one out.
